56.text: Well, I think it's . . . is it two years since the book was published?

60.text:
Anyway, it's rather nice to be meeting up again
so we can talk about it

63.text:
Indeed . . . yes
I'm beginning to get a bit fusty about one or two things

66.text: I'm sure you remember more than I do.

68.text:
No, but something you were very much concerned with
was folk-singing

72.text: and Chapter 16, which is the pastimes for the men.

74.text:
Yes, yes, indeed. Yes
I've always been involved with  . . . well, if not sport it's folk-music.

82.text:
and of course, as you know, I ran the sessions at The Oyster [pub]
for twenty years – over twenty years, actually

88.text:
That was in that inner room, wasn't it,
that was only open on Sunday evenings.

91.text:
Yes, in fact, when I first went to The Oyster,
it was open before I actually moved to Butley.

96.text:
It was open this particular time for a party for an American
who was going back to the States, I think it was,

101.text:
and the people in the old boys in the village said
“Well, we 'ent bin in 'ere for years” they said. So . . .

107.text:
That was Vera, the old landlady who was very set
in her ways, wasn't she.  Vic: That's right. Yes, yes

113.text:
But she did allow us to go in there when the numbers
attending the 'sing arounds' reached more than forty

118.text:
because you could hardly squeeze those
into the so-called Men's Kitchen, which was a small bar

122.text:
And, of course, in the corner was the piano
which you weren't allowed to play

125.text:
Well, I was allowed to sit on it.
I could rest one buttock on it.

134.text:
So, yes . . . that was where the person who chaired the
'sing arounds' could make his authority felt.

139.text: How many local people were really the singers.

142.text:
It depends how you define 'local' really, but within ten miles around,
I mean, I suppose, not all at the same time.

150.text:
But there must have been at least twenty performers,
I should think.

152.text:
and usually, there was a good dozen each time.
It was difficult to get everyone in for two songs.

156.text:
What I especially appreciated – because I was digging on
Burrow Hill and I used to bring students in,

161.text: who loved to see what was happening.

163.text:
What I most enjoyed was really the way you
conducted proceedings.

167.text:
I think you were called “The Chairman”,
 that was the traditional name.

170.text:
and you used to invite people to sing, and then suggest
who would follow and you would keep a sort of balance

176.text:
Well, that was the aim and the idea of being a Chairman
was derived from Wickets Richardson at Blaxhall Ship

182.text:
who used to use a cribbage board to bang on the table
to get good order but

186.text:
they were so well behaved at Butley
I didn't have to do that.

190.text:
But even so, tempers can get a bit frayed,
can't they?

193.text:
I've heard an old tape of people at The Ship,
and they're quite grumpy, the really old ones

200.text:
and they seem to be fussy about which song . . .
who's singing which song.

204.text:
That was certainly an issue in the old days,
shall we say

207.text:
But we were . . . we modern people didn't, er . . .
didn't insist on, you know

211.text:
But people didn't sing someone else's song, did they?
They tended not to. No No.

215.text: Or certainly if they were there

217.text:
No . . . that would be even more . . .
Yes.

220.text:
Because I've got a friend who's called Steven and you know him.
But he's known to everybody as Tom because of his song.

226.text:
He used to sing Tom Bowling
was the song he sang as . . . yes, his piece

229.text:
Yes
and I expect there are other examples of that

232.text:
Well, I can't just off the top of my head,
think of any

235.text:
But I'm sure there are. I was known as Waley Fish
because I used to sing a song about the Waley Fish

239.text:
Well, there you go!  But never to my face
I only discovered it after years. Anyway, there we go

245.text:
And I recall that you organised a gathering of people
coming from a great distance

250.text:
in Blaxhall Village Hall,
when The Ship was no longer used for singing.

256.text:
Well, that all originated back in 1974.
There was a record made by Topic, I think it was

263.text:
in Blaxhall Ship, called "The Larks they Sang Melodious",
and I had one song on that

267.text:
And someone, a friend of mine, got in touch with me in 2004
and said "What about a reunion!"

273.text:
But, of course, many of the people had moved away or died
and all the older singers had gone

277.text:
But we did try to use all the songs that had been sung
on that original recording

283.text:
on this reunion . . .
and, of course, you actually recorded some of that

288.text:
Well, that was a coincidence, really, because fortunately
I asked everybody, through you, if they minded if I recorded it

295.text:
and I had the smallest little recorder
and then we . . . well, thanks to my friend Chris Farmer

301.text:
who edited it, we made a CD to raise money for
the Village Hall, which was really . . .

307.text:
So that still exists as a record of the singing
Yes, indeed. Yes

311.text:
Now we first met, of course, again, I mentioned 1974
It must have been about that time, I should think

318.text:
When I lived in Butley
and you came to Burrow Hill

321.text:
That was '78
when I came to Burrow Hill to dig. Vic: Oh!

324.text:
I must have got the date wrong then
So you'll have to look at your diary, I expect

329.text:
and, well, you'd better say a bit about how you came
to be doing that

334.text:
Yes. It seems a long time ago
But I came to Burrow Hill because I was working in the British Museum
on research on the Sutton Hoo Ship Burial

342.text:
for the three great volumes that we've now got
to be the definitive publication of every object

350.text: Has that been superseded at all, yet?

353.text:
It never will be superseded as the definitive record and it was a lifetime's work
for my boss, Rupert Bruce-Mitford

361.text:
and he delegated to me, sort of, objects which weren't
particularly exciting in his eyes

367.text:
and one of them was the cauldron chain, which was a mass
of totally corroded ironwork and there was no free metal left

376.text: and I had two years hard labour, really, working out how it was built

380.text:
and, using radiographs, which come full-size,
and so everything was drawn up full-size

387.text:
And the day came when I could draw out all the components
and I got a very large sheet of tracing paper

393.text:
and then it went on and on and on, and it transpired
it's the longest cauldron chain known

400.text: What sort of length would it be?

401.text:
Yes, I can't remember that. I'd have to supply that bit of information
It just will not stick

406.text:
But what I do remember is the length of the little chain
that was found on Burrow Hill

412.text:
And the reason I visited Burrow Hill, was because I was looking for
other chains in the area

419.text:
and I was writing up the Chainwork Chapter, and nobody knew anything
about the Burrow Hill chamber

426.text:
which had been found by a ploughman in the '60s
and it was in bits in Ipswich Museum

432.text:
By that time I'd studied enough cauldron chains to know
how it should fit together

437.text:
and then found an old drawing which was actually in the British Museum
and had been posted by the curator of the British Museum

442.text:
so it was among the correspondence, showing how it was
when it was found. So that confirmed the order

449.text:
And there's a drawing of that in the sort of little article
I did on the site. So you can see

455.text: that shows you the fragments as they were in the museum

461.text:
and this is how it's been put together
Yeah Wonderful

465.text: and that's about six feet long

466.text:
And there is, in fact, a replica, isn't there, in the Ipswich Museum, now
Yes

472.text:
And what people do not, I think, on the whole, appreciate,
is what adjustable implements they were

481.text:
Because you can see, we've got hooks.
We've got a big ring at the top with a swivel

486.text:
so that the cauldron hanging on the bottom of the pot could rotate.
It's a sort of catch

494.text: and then you've got hooks on which things could be lifted up

498.text: So you could lift up the hooks, out of the way, it you weren't cooking

502.text:
or you could shorten the chain, below the hooks.
You could hang pokers or ladles on the hooks

508.text:
and of course, in those days you didn't have a roaring log fire.
You cooked with little bundles of faggots

514.text: So you had a very adjustable amount of heat

518.text: and the cauldrons have got quite thin skins

525.text:
cauldrons are very thin (the walls of cauldrons) and, of course,
they would burn out in no time at all

530.text:
if you did cook with them over a log fire. So what one finds
with Anglo-Saxon cooking is

535.text: it's all very slow cooking, rather like Irish peasant cooking

539.text:
Right
So, slow food didn't start recently, did it !

545.text: No . . . and, of course, it depends on the fuel that you have

548.text:
and peat, of course, which is used in Ireland very extensively,
was also available in Butley

553.text:
if you think about all the low ground. We have medieval records
of people digging peat. Yes

561.text: So one can think that that would be used as well as faggots to cook

566.text:
So there was evidence on the top of Burrow Hill for an Anglo-Saxon hoard.
Yes indeed

571.text:
The question was: where was it?
And I started digging to try to find it

576.text:
And, of course, much of the . . . much of the hill had been dug away
for gravel digging, hadn't it. Valerie: That was the sad thing

581.text: Vic: But I can actually tell you a little story about that because

583.text:
one of the men who had an allotment next to me
when I lived in Butley, was telling me how

589.text: when he came home from the First World War for leave

593.text:
the old 'roadman' who used to maintain the roads
before tarmac and so on

598.text:
he used to get gravel from Burrow Hill. He said "Them buggers
up at Burrow Hill sent me down some more skulls, they say"

606.text:
And because there were burials that were found up there,
weren't there?

609.text:
Well four of them ended up in the bank
by the old bullock yard at Oyster Hill

617.text:
And if you think about it, there would be human bone
under most of the roads on the estate

621.text: because they went up there for loads of gravel

626.text:
Yes. But, of course, by the time I came to dig there
nearly all the top of the hill had been dug away

633.text:
So we were only digging around the very rim of what had been
a very important Anglo-Saxon site

639.text:
Yes.
Well it was a settlement site and a cemetery

644.text: and, I think one can say, the church as well, was there

647.text:
If for no other reason than
because we've got that tiny piece of red glass

653.text: Yes, that would have come from the church window

657.text: It all seem a very long time ago now

659.text: Are you talking about Anglo Saxons, or us ?

683.text:
Do you know what really started it all, our writing the book?
It was a coin !

689.text: A coin, about as big as my, oh, that fingernail

692.text:
that I found with the team on Burrow Hill
at the end of one season

697.text:
When . . . and you weren't there. And of course, when you find coins
on Burrow Hill you keep pretty quiet about them

703.text:
and this coin was the only one of its type known
It still is the only one known

708.text:
of a king of East Anglia who's only mention is in the writings
of a monk . . .  a Durham monk

718.text: in the thirteenth century, and so this coin was so special

723.text:
Obviously, we didn't tell people and I suppose I should apologise
at this late stage

727.text:
that I didn't immediately get in touch with you
Well, I am very upset, of course!

732.text: So, when you did discover from a lecture you went to

736.text: you quite rightly wanted to know a bit more about it

739.text:
What haven't I been told in the last twenty years
. . .  sort of thing

741.text:
and of course, it was about
well, it was just before the year 2000, I suppose

745.text:
which was the year I retired, although I did carry on
working part-time for a company

751.text:
for another two years, and I got involved with a
voluntary organisation as well. But anyway, that all

757.text:
And of course, you were also living in Woodbridge, so
I was in Woodbridge. Yes

760.text:
It's not that I hadn't kept up my interest in Butley, of course
No, no. But, not so easy to call in on

770.text:
If you remember, it was almost accidental
You'd been doing the history of your house

775.text:
and some research into the village history of Butley,
hadn't you?

779.text:
Yes. I'd been on a course, actually, back in 1986,
I think it was, that got me really inspired

786.text:
and, yes, I had looked into the history of the house
which I'd actually been able to discover relatively easily

792.text:
and I thought, "Oh, this history business, there's nothing to it really!"
Until you discover of course, that there's a lot more to it

798.text:
Of course, at an earlier stage of the research, you'd said,
after about six months

802.text:
you said . . .
"Well, you can go on doing research forever. I think we should write it now"

804.text:
And I was, sort of feeling, there were so many holes
that we hadn't really got the first base

809.text:
But then, at that stage, I think you were thinking of
something quite modest

814.text:
and I quite keen that we did something which really put the history
of this forgotten peninsula on the map

823.text:
And of course, we did find it very difficult to fill in some of the periods,
didn't we – the eighteenth century, I think

828.text: The eighteenth century was the hardest, really, wasn't it?

830.text:
It was one of the worst, and we decided to cut out the really early things
It was just a mention of Burrow Hill, incidentally

837.text:
So we didn't plod through the thing in a sort of simply
chronological style, did we

843.text:
We, we, well in fact, we didn't have a book plan.
We wrote topics, didn't we.  Vic: Yes, yes

848.text:
and again, you were a bit concerned
And I said "Oh, it will fit itself together eventually"

852.text:
And of course, we had to, well I mean, the fact was that you
were living near Southampton

857.text:
and I was here in Suffolk for most of the time.
Well, nearly all of the time, wasn't it.

861.text:
It wasn't so easy to get together . . .
and, of course, we did meet at the National Archives, on occasions

866.text:
and of course,
an example of how material gets spread around

872.text:
I mean, manorial records for Butley were in
Ipswich Record Office,

876.text:
Bury St Edmunds Record Office and the British Library.
We went there as well, didn't we.

879.text:
So they were in those three different locations
Yes

883.text:
And then of course, you're never quite sure when something
will turn out to be really important, to shed light

890.text:
You wade through large, large vellum documents of
medieval gobbledegook,

895.text:
hoping there's going to be one little clause
buried somewhere in there

898.text:
talking in a tiny whisper, because you can't speak in the Record Office
and you're trying to help each other

905.text:
Well I think it was the National Archives that are the worst
I kept getting this frog in my throat as I was

909.text:
and you were tapping on to the laptop as I was saying
"Mutter, mutter, cough, cough"  "Shhhh"

917.text: That's right, and we'd had sessions doing this

919.text:
and when you put in a ticket for something,
you're never quite sure

922.text:
if it's going to be a small book or one of these enormous things
arriving on a trolley

927.text:
And we put in – do you remember – for the case of arson between
. . . was it Punt . . .

932.text:
Punt and Denney. Punt and Denney
Arson, it was, in Butley, wasn't it

937.text:
Yes, and it was . . . and that was a case that had been brought
to the King's Court in Westminster, hadn't it

942.text:
So we were expecting a trolley to arrive,
and it was a single sheet of paper!

946.text:
And it wasn't really arson
Well, it could have been arson but it was all to do with

951.text:
finding of silver – which almost certainly had come from
Butley Priory, and had been stolen

955.text:
It was 1540, just after the Dissolution, wasn't it – the closure of it –
and this hemphouse was on fire

962.text:
(presumably it was the thatch) and in the thatch they found
this silver which had almost certainly been stolen

967.text:
And that was really the reason this
Deposition had reached the King

972.text:
Nothing to do with arson. It was a little shed that had
burnt down! But it was what was in it

977.text:
And we'd always been mystified that when the
commissioners came to make an inventory of Butley Priory

983.text:
they said there was nothing in it worth anything but the lead
Nothing in it except lead and cattle, wasn't it

988.text: So we wanted to know where the silver had gone

990.text:
Of course, some monastic houses smuggled it abroad, didn't they,
to the parent houses   Vic: Did they. Yes

998.text:
And of course, it was the ex-warrener
(well, you'd probably see there was a warrener)

1001.text:
the man who'd been a warrener
at the priory at the time of the Dissolution

1007.text:
was one of the . . .  deponents
of the people who were telling the story

1012.text:
of how there were out batfowling
And do you remember the fun about batfowling?

1015.text:
Well, neither of us, we both, sort of tried to guess
what batfowling could be

1019.text: and you'd typed it up on your . . .

1022.text:
laptop
No, I didn't have a laptop in those days, and

1025.text:
It was a spell-check or something
which accepted it !

1028.text:
Yes, it threw me completely !
So I then had to look in the Oxford Dictionary

1032.text:
and discovered it was not,
not fowling bats, as we thought

1036.text:
but batting fowls
In other words, knocking them off their perches in the night

1040.text:
and catching them in the nets
Valerie: So they were poaching, weren't they

1044.text:
Well . . .
either poaching or it was with the permission of the land-owner

1047.text:
It's just possible, I suppose. But anyway I don't know
Valerie: Oh right

1049.text:
That's guesswork isn't it
Valerie: Yes

1052.text:
Yes, so, then, gradually we started to compile
as you say, these sort of chapters

1058.text:
Well they weren't chapters at that stage
they were just subjects, weren't they

1061.text:
Because if you haven't got a body of information ready
you don't quite know were your research is going to take you

1067.text:
so you can't really create an entity as a subject
And another wonderful thing was that letter from Elizabeth Forth

1074.text:
Oh, yes, in Norwich Record Office
Valerie: Another single sheet of paper

1078.text:
Yes indeed, which they got catalogued as a 17th century
(I think it was) or 18th century letter

1084.text:
but they had no idea what it was about
And we were able to say, well actually, it was written in May 1593

1089.text:
from London to Elizabeth Forth's sister.
Valerie: By one of our key characters

1096.text:
of the Forth heir, who'd made this disastrous marriage
to a Catholic girl, who'd written the letter

1102.text: Vic:  Yes, to her sister, in Norfolk

1104.text:
Most of the documents we have are, sort of official in some form
or another, so they're sort of edited or slanted by lawyers

1111.text:
But that was, that was, she was pouring out her heart
to her sister. So that was really moving

1123.text:
Valerie: Do you remember a local historian who lived in Woodbridge ?
George Arnott

1126.text: I know of him. I never met him though, did you?

1129.text:
Yes, I met him with my boss in the British Museum,
Rupert Bruce-Mitford

1133.text: because George had a Garden Party in his little walled garden

1137.text:
which was just near the market square in Woodbridge
Yes. I know where that is. Yes

1140.text:
and of course, Rupert was treated almost like
visiting royalty or the Pope

1144.text:
and all kinds of people brought sherds they'd found
in Mohenjo-daro or wherever

1149.text: for pronouncement from the great man

1152.text:
So that was my meeting of George Arnott, and of course
he was immensely knowledgeable

1156.text:
and he and his father who were Estate Agents and Auctioneers
I think that was their business

1163.text:
had had access to house clearances and sales
through the years

1168.text:
and so he'd been able to collect a large number of documents
and he wrote three small wonderful books

1175.text:
Vic: The Orwell Estuary . . . one was called the
Valerie: Orwell?  Is it?

1180.text:
Vic: Anyway the three main rivers, wasn't it
Valerie: Yes, of Suffolk

1184.text:
The reason they're so good is, not only did he have
the historical knowledge but he was a sailor

1189.text:
so the one I first read was about Burrow Hill,
naturally, so it was about the river

1197.text:
and he had anchored just under the cliffs of Gedgrave and
looked at Burrow Hill. So it was a really lovely evocation of it

1207.text:
But something he said in that book was the idea,
he mentioned the idea

1213.text: that Carlton, in Domesday, could have been located at Chillesford

1219.text:
And of course, in the survey, one of the entries for
the Carlton Manor is next to the Chillesford entry

1225.text:
and George obviously realised that and then he picked up
the Carlton place-name which was attached to the mill

1235.text:
What we now know as Butley Mills (plural)
was at one point, had three names, didn't it

1240.text:
Alias . . . Butley alias . . . Chillesford . . .  alias Carlton
Yes

1245.text:
And of course, now, looking back after all our work, I think we can
see how it came to have this funny mixture of names

1251.text:
because it was the conflation of what had been
three separate mills, once.  Yes.

1257.text:
And the third mill we identified as coming from the south of
the parish because of an old . . .  well, an 18th century map

1267.text:
which had Carlton and Mill place-names on the stream
which ran down from Capel Green

1274.text: and ran along Stonebridge . . .  across the marsh

1277.text:
And of course, when the river walls were built and the rivers
drain that valley (the streams round the rivers)

1284.text:
were all organised and rationalised, that particular mill,
and the stream, disappeared.   Yes.

1291.text:
They were no longer needed. So the Carlton Mill, the name,
was relocated up to the main outlet in the north, the Butley line

1303.text:
Vic: The estuary
Valerie: And then we had a boundary dispute with the relocation of the mill

1307.text: because there was something like 75 feet of land,

1311.text:
which had once been Butley's land
moved into Chillesford land

1315.text:
because they moved the mill to another outlet to slip it down
and that's in the Court Records!  Vic: Yes, indeed

1320.text:
And that's wonderful. They got very cross about this
and so they took a big stone and cart and planted it there

1330.text:
So there was, every now and then
there's a lovely insight into village life

1334.text:
And of course, the other manor that I don't think it was
entirely located the exact location in the

1341.text:
in the Suffolk version of the Domesday Book (the Suffolk translation)
was the Laneburgh Manor which

1350.text:
Yes. Well there are two volumes, aren't there
We've got a map here, which is very tiny with numbers on

1353.text:
but Laneburgh is put way out in Hollesley, somewhere in Hollesley,
I think.  Vic: Right.

1358.text:
and again, we were able to, again, from an old document,
wasn't it a 14th century document is it, here

1364.text:
able to say, well it's part of what is now Boyton Parish
In fact it's near what's called Scotland Fen, these days, isn't it

1372.text: When you look at the parish map of Boyton,

1375.text:
you can get a very good idea of where Laneburgh was,
because there's the funny bulge

1379.text:
what is now Scotland Fen, another problem of a place-name
Yes

1384.text:
And we found the reason for Scotland Fen, because various
local people were convinced it related to a time of great poverty

1392.text:
when Scotsmen drove their cattle down and took poor land
and grazed

1399.text:
and we were able to identify a Duchess's gamekeeper,
Scottish gamekeeper.  Vic: Yes.

1408.text:
Moving the posts out on the heathland, where of course
there are no distinguishing features really out there, were there

1413.text:
except the little mound called, The Spy,
which the shepherds would climb to be able to find their sheep. Yes

1419.text:
Sheep on the heath. Valerie: So it was the Duchess of Hamilton.
It was in our difficult 18th century period

1426.text:
and it was a Scottish gamekeeper who came down and tried to filch
a few acres for the Duchess from whoever it was.

1433.text: I can't remember quite who it was, now. But anyway

1436.text:
It was the Boyton, was it not the Boyton Trustees who were involved in that?
The Almshouse trustees

1440.text:
Which is why the record survived because, of course, they were very careful
in keeping the accounts of things and various transactions.  Yes

1446.text:
So one can imagine the Boyton people getting very cross
about this, you know, Scottish gamekeeper.

1452.text:
and calling it, Little Scotland, you know, he's made Little Boyton
Little Scotland. Yes

1504.text:
Something that is important to mention is the way this book
is trying to appeal to a great many different people

1512.text:
People with different levels of interest. We were very keen that
the villagers and local people would find it interesting

1519.text:
and judging by their reactions, they do, and some of them say
"I keep it by my bed"

1525.text:
or "I will never . . ." you know . . . "every page has got
something of interest". That's the sort of thing they say.

1533.text:
And then, we wanted it to be useful for people who were doing
local research, so we've mentioned a lot of the local people

1541.text:
who are involved in different activities . . .
and there's a good index for that.

1546.text:
And then, we really wanted it to be an academic book
which of course, it doesn't appear to be.

1551.text:
of course, the title doesn't help with Untold Tales
it sounds a bit . . .    Yes

1554.text:
Valerie: But Untold Tales is really
Vic: It draws other people in though, doesn't it

1557.text:
Valerie: Well, we're really saying this is unpublished,
otherwise unpublished historical research.   Vic: Research yes

1563.text:
and at the back, if you can flip through to find where we've written,
in small print, haven't we,

1568.text: the reference and the documentary details of everything.

1574.text:
We've got different kinds of bibliographies
We've got a glossary, and then . . .  these . . .

1580.text: every page has the sources for what we have written.

1585.text: And I think in that, we have been really obsessively careful

1588.text:
to give a really good working tool for any serious historian.
Vic: For anyone to follow. Yes.

1595.text:
And that of course, is something I suspect academics
haven't picked up on yet.  Vic: No. Maybe not.

1600.text:
I mean, that was the most difficult
well, apart from some of the, some of the Latin, I will confess

1606.text:
I did rely very . . .  oh well, entirely on you
But that's one of the hardest things to decide

1613.text:
where to pitch the book really. Who was the readership.
Yes.

1617.text:
and you could easily fall between two stools,
or you could become obsessively . . .  the general reader

1624.text:
and secondly, for the historian.
But . . .

1626.text:
Again, if you flip again.
Yes.

1628.text:
One or two people have said that we've done very well, you know,
historians – that we've done very well to, you know, balance it in that way.

1637.text:
But we've used boxes, haven't we,
so we've enabled people either to focus on something

1643.text:
I mean, here's pipes, so some people have found pipes
in their gardens, so they'll look at that.

1647.text:
Or, it's been some quite difficult area, which is to explain something
in the story without interrupting the narrative.

1655.text: And then of course, at the beginning of a chapter,

1657.text:
which, I have to say . . . this idea . . .  I picked up from
a wonderful American academic (now dead) Lionel Casson.

1664.text:
He's written a marvellous book on ships and seamanship
in the ancient Mediterranean

1669.text:
and he's had this larger print first page
telling you what's in the chapter, so you know

1677.text:
and then it gradually gets smaller print as he gets to the
more academic footnotes.  Vic: Oh, I see.

1681.text:
Which means you can get to things very, very easily.
Of course, that was another issue.

1684.text: Do you have footnotes or do you put them at the end?

1686.text:
People are put off by footnotes, aren't they, it interrupts the read
Yes exactly.

1692.text: Oh I'll tell you something quite interesting.

1694.text:
I've just seen this name . . . Joseph Arch here,
who was the founder of the Agricultural Workers Union

1701.text:
back in the 1870s, and he actually came to Butley when the
big strike was on in 1876, I think it was.

1711.text:
and he took tea at The Oyster Inn because he was a Methodist
and therefore was a teetotaller

1716.text:
and he addressed the labourers in Woodbridge
where they used to congregate and march round the town

1722.text:
saying "No tyranny!"
And there's that lovely expression where one of them described . . .

1727.text:
"We come marching in like soldiers . . .
but we go home like a flock of sheep."

1731.text:
And that was quoted, I think in The Times [newspaper]
because it was a Times correspondent who wrote up about the . . .

1738.text:
Anyway when I was having a rambling holiday just earlier this year
I went to a village called Barford in Warwickshire

1744.text:
and I knew Joseph Arch came from Warwickshire
and there's a pub there called the Joseph Arch Inn, or pub

1751.text: Well I hope you didn't just have tea in it.

1753.text:
No, it was Happy Hour !
I actually joined the Happy Hour for a few minutes.

1757.text: I was only just in time for that.

1758.text:
and of course, he was born in the village and died in the village
and his house is still there

1763.text:
almost opposite the hotel that we were staying in.
Isn't that incredible.  Valerie: Yes. Yes. Lovely.

1768.text:
Presumably you knew more than any of your colleagues about all this?
Oh that's the trouble, you see

1773.text:
The previous year (well, we're really digressing now) but when we went
to near Swindon I was telling them about the fritillery meadows there

1779.text:
They think Harrup knows everything, but of course, he doesn't !
Yes

1788.text:
And of course, getting illustrations. I was very . . .
Oh, that was your . . .

1791.text: Yes I know, you didn't really think illustrations were . . .

1793.text:
and then your children sort of informed you
that they are jolly important.

1799.text:
I didn't know how far and wide you were prepared to travel and
get permissions to reproduce them.

1808.text:
Yes. Some were very difficult. But it was lovely to try
to find the odd picture of a local person which told a story.

1815.text:
And this one I'm particularly fond of . . .  Louise Reeve,
because local people had told me about her as a old woman.

1821.text:
And there was this lovely photograph of her in her uniform
as a Forestry (I don't know what her term was)

1828.text:
but she was employed along with a team of young women
to plant the forest

1833.text:
which was such a feature of the landscape
before the Great Storm.

1838.text:
And they just, it was just harrowed by a horse
and then these girls planted, by hand, these thousands of saplings

1844.text:
And she's got a badge, you see, in her hat, and huge pockets.
Probably she kept her lunch in there

1852.text:
This is a lovely one, isn't it?
This picture of Claud Reed with his tractor.

1857.text: Vic: Yes. He's had to give up farming now.

1862.text:
So it's . . .  and of course, it does cover really,
pretty well from . . .  the tail end of the priory

1870.text:
We didn't deal with the priory in great detail, partly because
I suppose it's . . .  well, we

1875.text: When you say we didn't . . .  repeating

1878.text:
I thought it was jolly important that we didn't just repeat
already published information.

1882.text:
We were trying . . .  because that would have unbalanced the book,
for a start . . .  and it's been well published.

1888.text:
and the local historians brought it all together in a neat booklet
recently. So in a way that freed us, not to do that

1894.text:
and to concentrate on the personalities
and particularly that difficult period at the Dissolution

1901.text:
to see how much continuity there was with the staff
and what happened

1905.text:
And of course, the wonderful thing was the list of all the people
who were at the priory on the day it was closed

1911.text:
with all their trades
like I said, the warrener, earlier

1914.text:
Yes, and on a serious level, it was good to examine
the difference in agricultural practices or not

1921.text:
between the monastic organisation and, you know,
the capitalist farming entrepreneurs.  Yes.

1928.text: and to look at the affect on this particular area

1933.text:
which quite often doesn't fit the sort of broad brush
(I suppose) generalisation.

1939.text:
I don't know what the analyses of people who are
looking historically on a bigger scale

1945.text:
Yes
I think the Sandlings probably don't fit some of the patterns

1949.text:
For instance, we don't have nuclear villages for the most part.
They're scattered, aren't they.

1953.text:
People always assume (local people) that was the plague, you know
and not understand this represents an earlier pattern.

1962.text:
And also, of course, the other thing.
Well, it was a revelation to me really

1966.text:
because I always thought that the heathland
was virtually uncultivatable

1970.text: until recent years when the irrigation was introduced.

1973.text:
But in fact, there were periods when they were planted
with arable crops, or parts, large parts were, weren't they.  Yes.

1985.text:
And something else we looked at were woodland
and see just how little of it was wooded

1990.text:
And I found this hard to understand
And I thought, in the past, of the importance of timber on every level

1996.text:
for fuel and tools, carts, houses . . .
 . . .  a great demand

2001.text:
and then you look, that we didn't have Enclosure Acts here
because the land had been enclosed centuries before

2007.text:
for the most part, apart from the big sheep walks.
And so the plots tend to be about an acre

2013.text:
because that's what is easily ploughed within
is it, for one team, in a . . .  I'm trying to remember

2019.text:
It must be a day
Otherwise they wouldn't have done the job properly

2023.text:
And of course, that depends on the soil, doesn't it
Well of course. Yes

2025.text:
And of course, the hedges round the fields all had trees growing in them.
So this was in lieu of woodland

2031.text:
you had your timber supply was round your fields.
Vic: Yes

2035.text: And we haven't . . .  we've got Staverton as an old woodland

2039.text:
which of course, was a park but not a deer park
for the greater part of its life.

2045.text:
We think, right at the beginning it probably was, and it is now
because the Kemballs are already there

2051.text:
But it was a huge resource for pasture and for forage in bad
weather, you know, sheep were kept alive on holly branches

2060.text:
the ones that go high up, about three quarters of the plant.
And of course, it was used for

2065.text:
I found one particular will, where he talked about his 'wethers'
which are sheep, aren't they, male sheep, I think

2073.text:
in Staverton Park
and his bullock in there, or something like that

2076.text: Anyway, certainly part of it, probably the part that was not

2080.text:
where most of the trees had been removed at some stage
or perhaps were never there.  Yes

2083.text:
I don't know, but within the park perimeter
animals were kept

2090.text:
Copyholders would keep their animals there.
Almost like a Common I suppose, in a way

2096.text:
Though perhaps they only leased it or something like that,
rather than have Common Rights.

2099.text: But, as a detail, we don't know.  No.

2102.text:
And of course, if you look at the Norden Map you can see
that Staverton Park which is beautifully portrayed

2107.text:
he doesn't show an even spread of trees.
There are areas which are 'un-treed'

2110.text:
and a strip down the side which is cultivated.
Vic: Yes.

2115.text:
And then there are the sort of tiny woodlands
which exist in the priory

2121.text:
I think I worked out the proportion, it's a very small
proportion that is wooded,

2125.text:
and Little Heywood over between Capel and Boyton
is really the oldest wood that we've got

2131.text:
The one that people think that is so old, which is the one
by the priory which is now called Water Wood.  Yes.

2138.text:
in the past was called Asholt Wood.
Exactly the same size at the Dissolution as it is today.

2144.text: but was described as "an indifferent plantation"

2148.text:
in other words not a natural wood.
But it had been coppiced Ash because it's 'Asholt'

2153.text:
which would have been tremendously valuable.
It's the most valuable wood for fire and for tools

2158.text:
and it's close to the priory's yard where all these
activities took place

2164.text:
And it's, of course, where all the daffodils grow and
which Richard Mabey featured in his radio programme this year

2172.text:
And of course, they spread all across that valley, don't they
up into what is now Oak Wood.  Yes

2179.text:
which used to be called Water Wood
and when you walk in it you can see why

2183.text: There are springs up there which make it permanently damp

2187.text: Which was the other wood, the Belle . . .

2190.text:
Belle Goodwin's. That was in private hands
That wasn't the manorial . . .

2195.text:
part of the wood and if you look at it, you can see it's coppice.
Right.

2199.text:
Whereas the Great Wood, as it was called
when it wasn't called Water Wood or Oak Wood

2204.text: has got a few oak trees – big oaks.

2207.text:
But if you look at them, they're all stunted or twisted.
There's something wrong.  Yes.

2212.text:
and that's because Walter . . .
(gosh, what was he called, beginning with 'B') Walter Boynton

2217.text: Vic: Oh the old man. You mean Boynton, in the [19]20s

2221.text:
Walter Boynton, in the 20s, bought this large part
of the estate for next to nothing,

2228.text:
and he bought it with his wife's railway money
because they lived at Melton Grange

2236.text:
and he was stuck for cash and so he ripped out all the trees
and he used machine-chains to drag them out

2244.text:
And so he took out all the trees of any quality
from that wood

2248.text:
and the ones that are left are the ones that weren't any use
or of no value

2252.text:
And that's why the tracks are so deeply rutted
It's the result of Walter's activities

2257.text:
Yes, he did a lot of damage, didn't he
Valerie: Yes

2260.text:
Well . . .  one finds these cycles of prosperity and depression
that have an appalling effect on local people.

2271.text:
Dearth and Plenty, I think
did we call it that at some point?

2280.text:
I was just wondering about our list of . . .
list of people at the priory

2289.text:
Because we've got the warrener, was it?
We broke them down differently. Didn't we do the children separately?

2296.text:
I thought there was no point in just reproducing it
as everybody reproduced it

2302.text:
We broke it down differently. Yes
It helps you to see if you've got any relatives there

2309.text: Yes. The children are listed somewhere.

2312.text:
But I was thinking . . .  yes, I think . . .
I did a huge amount of work on transcribing wills

2320.text:
and several of the people who actually were listed
as part of the household of the priory

2327.text:
in other words, the lay people who worked on the farm
(there were nearly 70 of them, I believe)

2332.text:
I mean, we're talking about 5000 acres, and a lot of it would be
heathland, of course, and not a lot of labour needed for it.

2341.text:
Yes, what I found with all these wills,
and there must have been several hundred I must have transcribed,

2346.text: is that it's often more interesting

2349.text:
although little bits that appear on the original will that don't appear
on the copy that was made for the ecclesiastical court.

2355.text:
because all the wills had to be cleared.
The probate had to be granted by an ecclesiastical court.

2362.text:
And sometimes there was a little bit added at the bottom
that they wouldn't transcribe because it wasn't necessary.

2367.text:
And one of them I particularly liked
was one of the canons at the priory had written this will

2375.text:
Well, for a man who had died
but his widow was being referred to

2379.text:
when he put a note at the bottom, addressed to a Master Cente
(who I presume was one of the ecclesiastical officers)

2386.text:
and saying "Please be kind to this poor woman (meaning the widow)
because this is the first will I have ever written."

2395.text:
And so he was worried that he hadn't written it in such
legal terms that would enable her to

2401.text:
be the proper beneficiary of her deceased
husband's will.

2406.text:
And then there was another case, around about 1540
where someone wrote at the end of the will

2413.text:
that he was riding past this house in Hollesley
where a man lay dying, and he said to him

2420.text: "You ought to get 'so-and-so' to witness your will"

2426.text:
and don't forget [in effect]
to surrender your copyhold to me."

2432.text:
because it was the manorial lord of Wantisden
who actually was writing it

2436.text:
So again, little insights into how things worked really.
I mean, I've often wondered with wills

2442.text:
how they managed to be (most of them) very well written really.
Especially, think of those that were written in Latin

2448.text:
They must have been rehearsed in advance it seems to me.
Yes.

2452.text:
Or the scrivener who is fluent in Latin
is taking the instructions from the ill person

2458.text:
and actually writing it in a form which the author . . .
nobody can actually read !

2465.text:
I can't picture that happening because I did read one will, where,
actually, it was rehearsed before whatever it was, the priest

2472.text:
I suppose it was, and I just wonder whether in fact,
sort of like, notes were taken and then it was written up

2479.text:
Unless of course, it was desperate, and the person
was on the point of death and this was not possible.

2485.text:
But when you think of really long wills
there's no way you could take it down at the time, I don't think

2493.text:
because the person who is dying,
is going to be much more rambling

2496.text:
"Oh, and so-and-so. I must leave so-and-so to so-and-so."
Yes.

2498.text:
But of course, that brings up to another point.
Sometimes people have made their wills long before they die

2503.text:
when they are alright. And of course
it's always a danger for me to think "Oh the will date is the death date"

2509.text:
And then to later find, you know
a long search to find when

2512.text:
And even the probate can take four or five years because there's
been a dispute. So there are all these little nuances

2517.text:
that you need to be aware of . . .
and traps . . . I suppose you could say.  Yes.
